Apollo 11 Moon LOnDing


"That's one small step for man, one giant leap for mankind"

The Domain


On the 20th July 1969 Neil Armstrong became the first person to step foot on the moon, marking a historic moment for the whole of humanity, and realising one of the most era-defining feats of the 20th century.

Alongside Edwin “Buzz” Aldrin and Michael Collins, Armstrong reached the moon as part of the Apollo 11 Project, launched by President Kennedy in 1961, with the explicit aim of landing a man on the moon and returning him back to earth before the close of the decade.

However, the Apollo 11 project was not simply about space exploration, scientific innovation, and the widening of humanity’s horizons. At the time, the United States was in fierce competition with its Cold War adversary, the Soviet Union – a rivalry now referred to as the Space Race. The Space Race was not just a matter of technological superiority; it represented a battle between two ideologies, two ways of being, and two ways of ruling. The USA’s triumph in the Space Race was therefore hugely symbolic.

Nevertheless, despite bountiful documentary evidence, there are many who did – and still do – cast doubt upon the veracity of the Apollo 11 moon landing, viewing it as a large-scale, national-level conspiracy aimed at duping the world into believing in the might and power of the United States.

Moon LOnDing is a Linked Open Data project which seeks to explore the organisation and representation of knowledge connected to the Apollo 11 moon landing, focusing on three core narratives:

  • The historic and era-defining nature of the achievement, as evidenced in many references to the moon landing in popular culture throughout the decades
  • The political background which was the backdrop and impetus of the moon landing, namely the Cold War and the Space Race
  • The perduring doubts which surround the moon landing, manifest in the proliferation of conspiracy theories, despite physical evidence to the contrary

Objects


Ten objects relating to the Apollo 11 moon landing have been carefully selected to represent and interlink each of the aforementioned narrative threads (impact on popular culture, political background, doubts and conspiracies).

Knowledge Organisation


Conceptual Map


The first step in the process of organising knowledge related to the Apollo 11 moon landing was to create a conceptual map depicting basic and explicit data about each item, focusing loosely on the following questions:

  • Who created the item? Who was involved in the creation of the item?
  • When was the item created? What era/period does the item refer to?
  • Where was the item created? Where is it currently located?
  • What is the item about? What is it made from? What format is it in?

After creating a conceptual map for each individual item, we connected all our items together into one large conceptual map with the moon landing itself at the centre.


ER Model


As a second step in the knowledge organisation process, we converted our conceptual map into an entity-relationship model by abstracting from particulars to more platonic, universal concepts.

For example: the authors/creators of our items were converted into the generic class ‘person’; the specific dates of creation of our items were converted into the generic class ‘date’; the museums and cultural centres that house our items were converted into the generic class ‘institution’; our items themselves were converted into generic classes, such as ‘book’, ‘physical artefact’, ‘recording’, etc.


Metadata Scouting


In order to progress our organisation of knowledge relating to the Apollo 11 moon landing, we identified the metadata standards employed by the provider institution of each of our objects. Our findings are summarised below:


Metadata Alignment


To align our metadata standards we first categorised the informal, natural language predicates from our conceptual map and ER model into: who, what, where, and when.

We then decided upon which standards would be the most appropriate to represent each item. In this process we came to the following conclusions:

  • Since the metadata standards utilised by WorldCat were unclear, we decided to add Marc21 to our metadata alignment, which supplements the MODS standard used by other bibliographic items in our collection
  • Since the National Air and Space Museum uses TMS software to categorise its material objects, and since we did not have access to this software, we decided to substitute it with CIDOC-CRM

The metadata standards that we chose to align are therefore: Dublin Core, XML metadata format, DACS, EAD, Marc21, MODS, CIDOC-CRM, Schema, and LCDRG

Special Message to Congress on Urgent National Needs


A speech given by President Kennedy on the 25th May 1961, declaring his intention to put a man on the moon and to bring him back to earth by the end of the decade. It is held by the John F. Kennedy Library.

Waterloo


An episode from the 7th season of the TV show “Mad Men”, a series set in the 1960s. In this episode, we see not only the characters watch the moon landing on TV but we also witness the multifarious, and often discordant, opinions surrounding the event. The episode is referenced from its IMBD record.

Medal, Commemorative, Apollo 11


A medal created by Constantino Affer in honour of the moon landing, depicting Neil Armstrong as he takes his first steps on the moon. The medal is made from bronze using a high-relief technique. It is stored at the Steven F. Udvar-Hazy Centre, Virginia, a subsidiary of the National Air and Space Museum, whose main site is in Washington D.C.

First on the Moon


A book detailing the Apollo 11 project generally, as well as the moon landing and return to earth, published in 1970. Written by the crew who took part in the mission: Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Michael Collins. The book is referenced from its Library of Congress record.

Apollo 11 Launch Images Burgess: NASM-9A13960


One image from a collection of digitized images taken by Tim Burgess during a preflight press conference on 5th July 1969 at the NASA Manned Spacecraft Centre in Houston, Texas. The image depicts the crew of Apollo 11: Neil Armstrong, Buzz Aldrin, and Michael Collins. The images are held by the National Air and Space Museum, Washington D.C.

2001: A Space Odyssey


A science fiction novel written by Arthur C. Clarke and published in 1968. It depicts landing on the moon prior to it happening, offering a glimpse of contemporary imagination in this respect. The novel was written concurrently with Stanley Kubrick’s film version, of the same name. The book is referenced from its Library of Congress record.

Pressure Suit, A7-L, Armstrong, Apollo 11, Flown


The spacesuit worn by Neil Armstrong during the Apollo 11 mission, commissioned by NASA and made out of white beta cloth. It is held by the National Air and Space Museum, Washington D.C.

We Never Went on the Moon


A book propounding that the moon landing was a hoax, published in 1976. The book was written by Bill Kaysing, who worked at the Rocketdyne Propulsion Field Laboratory during the period in which the engine and components for the Apollo 11 project were planned. The book is referenced from its WorldCat record.

Man on the Moon


A song written and performed by the band R.E.M., released as the second single from their 1992 album “Automatic for the People”. The song reached number 30 on the US Billboard Hot 100 and number 18 in the UK Singles Chart. The song is referenced from its MusicBrainz record.

Memorandum to President Nixon


A speech written by speechwriter, William Saffire, for President Nixon. It contains the text of a speech that was prepared for the President in the case that the Apollo 11 crew were unable to return to earth following the moon landing, representing the danger of the mission they were undertaking. The document is held by the National Archives Catalogue of the United States.
